situation: A few players are playing a boardgame. The current state of the game is as follows. The chinchilla destroys the wall constructed by the owl. The cobra has four friends. The cobra does not refuse to help the camel. And the rules of the game are as follows. Rule1: If something calls the starling, then it invests in the company whose owner is the coyote, too. Rule2: If there is evidence that one animal, no matter which one, destroys the wall built by the owl, then the cobra is not going to reveal a secret to the goose. Rule3: If something does not fall on a square that belongs to the fangtooth and additionally not reveal a secret to the goose, then it will not invest in the company whose owner is the coyote. Rule4: Here is an important piece of information about the cobra: if it has more than 10 friends then it does not call the starling for sure. Rule5: The cobra will reveal something that is supposed to be a secret to the goose if it (the cobra) has a card whose color appears in the flag of Belgium. Rule6: The cobra will not call the starling if it (the cobra) is in France at the moment. Rule7: If you are positive that one of the animals does not refuse to help the camel, you can be certain that it will call the starling without a doubt. Rule3 is preferred over Rule1. Rule4 is preferred over Rule7. Rule5 is preferred over Rule2. Rule6 is preferred over Rule7.
question: Based on the game state and the rules and preferences, does the cobra invest in the company whose owner is the coyote?
label: proved
